Greenbelt Highlights (In No Particular Order)

I did the least program-wise but got the most out of GB this year, which I found interesting. I traveled alone, about 24 hours total from my door to my tent. I wandered most of the first day until Kester‚Äôs birthday celebrations that evening, when I expected to run into most people I knew. (I somehow ran into Steve Collins earlier which was nice to finally see a familiar face after a few hours at the festival.) And from that moment it was just chill uber- community. I am actually really having a hard time finding words. I felt more connected to the community here this year than I have in the past, and while I will admit that had something to do with Jenny Brown, it wasn‚Äôt entirely because of her. I think it is just one of those deals where the less agenda one has, even down to what programming one intends to consume, the more open one is to real moments of serendipity.

I‚Äôm in a coffee shop across from the train station, on my last few minutes of battery, trying to get my iPod charged for the journey to Swansea, where I‚Äôm off to to visit with Wood and his family. It will be very good to get clean and re-connected to the real world. Greenbelt was fairly perfect this year, even down to timing.

Soundtrack for the trip so far:

Salim Nourallah, off the new Snowing in My Heart: So Down, The Wicked are Winning

St. Vincent, off her debut: Jesus Saves, I Spend, Marry Me

Travis, off their latest: Closer, Big Chair
